Yesterday, we had a guest session by Ankur Warikoo for my tiny homegrown cohort-based course, Summit 21.

Of course, I asked him knowing in my head he’ll say no.

Why would somebody who talks to major companies come to my cohort? Why would somebody so busy say yes to me?

When I asked him, there wasn’t a followed up discussion. 

He said yes in minutes :)

So we had a fun-filled call with 33 students from across India, the U.S., England, Ireland, Singapore, Canada, and France. 

They've been a part of one of my Summit 21 cohorts in the past 18 months that I’ve been running it.

We spoke about
• an offbeat career path as a parent (since most of my students have kids)
• how to distraction-proof yourself in today's world
• making a living by following your bliss
• writing online + ideation + process
• and so much more... :)

One of our attendees made five pages of notes! Imagine, a LinkedIn post and a few bullets can't do justice to an hour-long value-packed session.

My biggest takeaways were:
• having a partner who's in sync with you can change everything
• use money to make life more comfortable so you can focus
• we don't have as much to lose as we think we do
• what would you rather be, if not humble?
• it's important to live, you'll die anyway

But again, these points do absolutely zero justice to how entertaining and inspiring it was to just watch him talk.

Also - when you want something, ask for it. The worst answer is only no. But what if it’s a yes? I learnt this from my experience of mustering a few seconds of courage to send him that text asking him to be a part of this, haha.

Today, I'm sinking in the exceptional response I've got from my students but also looking back to think that Summit 21 has come a long way. 

What I started as a fun experiment to see if what I teach actually works, is running its eighth full cohort attracting a global audience. I still have the feeling of not knowing how long it'll last.

But instead of focusing on that, I'm just going to *live* and chill out, as Warikoo says :)

During the starting of my career, I was consistently advised by my family and friends to 'network' well in the office.

And rightly so - networking can help you gain recognition at your workplace.

However, as an introvert, I often found it difficult to make small talks or network with my senior bosses/ colleagues.

But, I knew that I was a hard worker and my strong suit was research.

Hence, I decided to double down on that strength.

I would:
- do extensive research, 
- prepare exhaustive notes, and 
- add relevant pointers to project reports.

This helped me distinguish myself from my peers.

I eventually became the go-to person for any kind of project detailing and presentation. 

And, the senior bosses started noticing my efforts, and appreciated the value addition.

**********
This is what I learnt -

Networking is an important skill for getting noticed at the workplace, and progressing further in your career.

However, contrary to the popular opinion, networking can only get you so far.

The best way to earn recognition at work? - Be good at what you do.

Specifically, aim to become the expert or go-to person on the team when it comes to a particular task or issue.

Step up whenever a related need arises. 

Your boss and your coworkers will surely notice. And you wouldn't have to 'network' your way to the top.

How can we create a fulfilling career path that encourages our employees to embark on a growth journey within our organisation?

Back in the day, it was common for individuals to work for the same organisation for a good 15 to 20 years, perhaps even until retirement. But nowadays, it seems like people are sprinting from one opportunity to the next, barely sticking around for more than a couple of years.
At Suburban Diagnostics, we take pride in the fact that we have employees who have been with us for more than a decade.

First and foremost, it's important to provide opportunities for continuous learning and development. By offering training programs, mentorship opportunities, and access to industry resources, we empower our employees to hone their skills and expand their knowledge base.

Creating a career path also involves providing clear goals and opportunities for advancement. Our employees are encouraged to set personal and professional goals, and we work together to map out a path to achieve them. By aligning their aspirations with the organisation's vision, we enable our employees to see how their growth journey fits into the bigger picture. 

When employees feel valued and connected, they are more likely to envision a long-term future with us.

Personally, I enjoy having lunch with my teammates as it allows me to foster stronger connections with them. This provides a less intimidating environment, allowing for more open conversations and understanding personal aspirations.

WORKLIFE BALANCE is a MYTH...

While I was conducting my Skill Up Workshop, there were some people who wants to switch their jobs because there is no work life balance in the existing organisation.

I personally believe there is no such thing as WorkLife Balance.

When we start doing what we really enjoy, or
When we know the purpose behind what we are doing is strong enough, or
When we get the desired results from our work,
We never ask for a work life balance. 

Its a natural process. 

On the other hand, when we start cribbing about the work and its not solving the purpose anymore, we start making excuses that we don't get time for our family and our personal life.

Here are a few things which might eliminate the WorkLife Balance concept -

[1] Focus on being more productive

You will stop wasting your time on things that doesn't really matter.

[2] Identify your areas of interest and try to find the career opportunities around that.

It will require a bit of introspection & personal SWOT analysis.

[3] Set your priority list without regrets

I have seen a lot of people doing this - they do things which they know are important and yet not able to accept that reality happily. 

Your priority list should be your CHOICE and not COMPULSION.

[4] WorkLife Balance is not really a lifestyle, its a mindset

I hope this will help you have a different outlook at the concept of WorkLife Balance and help you overcome this mental loop.

To your Growth
